title: 1 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 19 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 19.

questions.question: Who told Jezebel all that Elijah had done, including slaying the prophets?
options: Ahab
Elijah
Hazael
Jehu
questions.correctAnswer: Ahab
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:1 states that Ahab told Jezebel all that Elijah had done and how he had slain all the prophets with the sword.

questions.question: What threat did Jezebel send to Elijah through a messenger?
options: She would make his life like the prophets by tomorrow
She would imprison him immediately
She would send the army after him
She would exile him from Israel
questions.correctAnswer: She would make his life like the prophets by tomorrow
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:2 records Jezebel's message threatening to make Elijah's life like those of the slain prophets by the next day.

questions.question: Where did Elijah go after leaving his servant in Beersheba?
options: Into the wilderness
To Mount Carmel
To Damascus
To Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: Into the wilderness
questions.explanation: According to 1 Kings 19:3-4, Elijah went a day's journey into the wilderness after leaving his servant in Beersheba.

questions.question: Under what type of tree did Elijah sit and wish for death?
options: Juniper tree
Olive tree
Cedars of Lebanon
Palm tree
questions.correctAnswer: Juniper tree
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:4 states Elijah sat under a juniper tree and requested that he might die.

questions.question: Who touched Elijah and told him to arise and eat while he was under the tree?
options: An angel
A prophet
A servant
A messenger
questions.correctAnswer: An angel
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:5 recounts that an angel touched Elijah and told him to arise and eat.

questions.question: What did Elijah find to eat and drink when the angel told him to arise?
options: A cake baked on coals and a cruse of water
Bread and wine
Fruits and milk
Manna and water
questions.correctAnswer: A cake baked on coals and a cruse of water
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:6 says Elijah saw a cake baked on coals and a cruse of water at his head, which he ate and drank.

questions.question: How long did Elijah journey in the strength of the food provided by the angel?
options: Forty days and forty nights
Seven days
Three days and three nights
One week
questions.correctAnswer: Forty days and forty nights
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:8 tells that Elijah went in the strength of that food for forty days and forty nights to Mount Horeb.

questions.question: What question did the word of the LORD ask Elijah when he was in the cave at Horeb?
options: What doest thou here, Elijah?
Why have you fled?
Who has sent you here?
Are you ready to serve?
questions.correctAnswer: What doest thou here, Elijah?
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:9 shows that the LORD asked Elijah, 'What doest thou here, Elijah?'

questions.question: Which phenomena did NOT contain the LORD when Elijah stood on the mount?
options: The wind, earthquake, and fire
The still small voice
The mountain itself
The cave
questions.correctAnswer: The wind, earthquake, and fire
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:11-12 explains that the LORD was not in the wind, earthquake, or fire but in the still small voice.

questions.question: Who was Elijah instructed to anoint king over Syria?
options: Hazael
Jehu
Elisha
Nimshi
questions.correctAnswer: Hazael
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:15 commands Elijah to anoint Hazael to be king over Syria.

questions.question: True or False: Elijah was to anoint Jehu the son of Nimshi as king over Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:16 confirms Elijah was instructed to anoint Jehu son of Nimshi as king over Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Elijah was the only one left faithful to the LORD in Israel according to his words.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:14-18 reveals Elijah thought he was alone, but God said 7,000 had not bowed to Baal or kissed him.

questions.question: True or False: Elijah cast his mantle upon Elisha while Elisha was plowing with twelve yoke of oxen.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:19 states Elijah passed by Elisha plowing with twelve yoke of oxen and cast his mantle upon him.

questions.question: Complete the verse: Elijah told Elisha, 'Go back again: for what have I ______ to thee?'
options: done
said
promised
asked
questions.correctAnswer: done
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:20 shows Elijah asked Elisha 'for what have I done to thee?'.

questions.question: What did Elisha do after he returned back from Elijah according to 1 Kings 19?
options: Slew a yoke of oxen and boiled their flesh for the people
Built an altar to Baal
Fled to another country
Became a prophet immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Slew a yoke of oxen and boiled their flesh for the people
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:21 says Elisha took a yoke of oxen, slew them, boiled their flesh with the instruments, and gave it to the people to eat.

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 19 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling overwhelmed and discouraged in their service for God, like Elijah did. Based on 1 Kings 19, what biblical truth would you share about God's provision and care?
options: God provides physical and spiritual sustenance through His angels and His word
God expects us to rely solely on our own strength without rest
God punishes those who feel discouraged without giving help
God only helps when we have no enemies
questions.correctAnswer: God provides physical and spiritual sustenance through His angels and His word
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 19:5-8, Elijah was physically sustained by an angel with food and water and strengthened for his journey, showing God’s care for our needs. Verses 9-13 further show God speaking to Elijah in a gentle, sustaining way.

questions.question: How does Elijah's response under the juniper tree teach us about dealing with despair and finding hope in God?
options: It teaches that we should openly express our feelings to God and seek His help
It teaches that despair means we have no faith
It teaches that running away is always the best solution
It teaches that we should ignore our emotions and keep working
questions.correctAnswer: It teaches that we should openly express our feelings to God and seek His help
questions.explanation: Elijah openly expressed his desire to die and his feelings of failure (1 Kings 19:4, 10, 14), showing that honest prayer and seeking God’s help during trials is biblical.

questions.question: What does God's presence in the 'still small voice' teach us about how God often works in our lives?
options: God often works quietly and gently, not always through dramatic events
God only works through dramatic signs like fire and earthquake
God is absent during trials and only appears in miracles
God favors loud and public displays over personal moments
questions.correctAnswer: God often works quietly and gently, not always through dramatic events
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:11-12 shows God not in the wind, earthquake, or fire, but in a still small voice, teaching us to be attentive to His gentle guidance and presence.

questions.question: A believer is afraid to obey God’s calling because of threats and opposition. What encouraging truth does Elijah’s story provide about obedience despite fear?
options: God strengthens and directs us to carry out His purposes even when we face danger
Fear means God is not with us and we should stop serving
Obedience guarantees immediate safety and no opposition
We should only obey when it is convenient and safe
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens and directs us to carry out His purposes even when we face danger
questions.explanation: Elijah fled for his life (1 Kings 19:3), yet God renewed his strength and gave him clear instructions to anoint kings and a prophet (1 Kings 19:15-16), showing obedience amid fear is supported by God.

questions.question: What does Elijah’s commissioning of Elisha teach us about mentorship and spiritual leadership in the church?
options: Spiritual leaders are called to raise up and invest in the next generation
Leadership is only about personal success and power
Mentorship is unnecessary if a person is gifted
Spiritual leadership should be done alone without help
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual leaders are called to raise up and invest in the next generation
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 19:19-21, Elijah calls Elisha to follow him and become a prophet, demonstrating the biblical principle of leaders mentoring others to continue God’s work.

questions.question: How does the passage encourage us to maintain integrity and faithfulness when others around us are unfaithful?
options: God has preserved a faithful remnant who have not bowed to Baal
We should give up when others turn away
We should conform to the majority to avoid conflict
Faithfulness is optional when surrounded by unfaithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: God has preserved a faithful remnant who have not bowed to Baal
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:18 assures that God has kept 7,000 faithful in Israel, encouraging believers to remain faithful despite widespread unfaithfulness.

questions.question: True or False: Elijah was the only prophet left faithful to God according to his own words in 1 Kings 19.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Elijah says he is the only one left (1 Kings 19:10, 14), though God reveals there are others faithful (verse 18), showing Elijah’s initial discouragement.

questions.question: True or False: Elijah obeyed God's command immediately without hesitation when told to anoint Hazael, Jehu, and Elisha.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The text shows Elijah obeyed God’s command to anoint these leaders by going and finding Elisha immediately (1 Kings 19:15-19), demonstrating prompt obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Elijah found Elisha while he was __________ with twelve yoke of oxen before him, and he with the twelfth.
options: plowing
fishing
praying
hunting
questions.correctAnswer: plowing
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:19 states that Elisha was plowing with twelve yoke of oxen before him, which shows his hardworking and diligent nature before being called.

questions.question: How does Elijah’s prayer and conversation with God in the cave encourage us in humility and contentment during trials?
options: It shows the importance of honestly expressing struggles to God and recognizing our human limitations
It teaches that we should always appear strong and never admit weakness
It implies that God ignores those who doubt
It encourages us to avoid solitude and prayer
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the importance of honestly expressing struggles to God and recognizing our human limitations
questions.explanation: Elijah’s prayer in 1 Kings 19:9-14 reveals his honest feelings of jealousy and despair, showing humility and dependence on God during hardship.

questions.question: What lesson does Elijah’s act of slaughtering oxen and sharing food with the people teach about generosity and stewardship?
options: Generosity involves sharing resources to nurture community and support fellowship
Stewardship means hoarding resources for personal use
Sharing food is unimportant in spiritual service
Generosity is only for the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: Generosity involves sharing resources to nurture community and support fellowship
questions.explanation: Elijah’s act in 1 Kings 19:21 to boil the oxen and feed the people demonstrates sharing and generosity as part of ministry and fellowship.

questions.question: How does Elijah’s interaction with Elisha model the importance of commitment and priorities in following God?
options: Elisha asked to say goodbye to his family before following, showing the balance of family loyalty and commitment to God
Elisha left immediately without regard to family
Following God means neglecting all family responsibilities
Priorities should always favor personal comfort over God’s call
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha asked to say goodbye to his family before following, showing the balance of family loyalty and commitment to God
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 19:20, Elisha requests to kiss his parents goodbye before following Elijah, respecting family while committing to God’s call.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with loneliness in their walk with God, feeling like they are the only faithful one. What hope does 1 Kings 19 offer about God’s faithfulness to His people?
options: God preserves a faithful remnant even when it seems we are alone
Faithfulness is rare and God abandons most people
Loneliness means we are not really faithful
God only cares about the majority
questions.correctAnswer: God preserves a faithful remnant even when it seems we are alone
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 19:18 reveals God has preserved 7,000 faithful in Israel, reassuring believers they are not alone in faith.

questions.question: How does Elijah’s journey to Mount Horeb teach about spiritual discipline and seeking God in solitude?
options: Seeking God often involves intentional solitude and quietness to hear His voice
God is only found in crowds and loud worship
Spiritual discipline means constant activity without rest
Solitude is a sign of failure in faith
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking God often involves intentional solitude and quietness to hear His voice
questions.explanation: Elijah’s travel to Horeb and time in the cave (1 Kings 19:8-13) illustrate the value of solitude for spiritual renewal and hearing God’s voice.

questions.question: What can we learn about perseverance from Elijah’s experience of fleeing, resting, and then continuing God’s work?
options: Perseverance includes times of rest and renewal before continuing the mission God has given us
Perseverance means never stopping or resting under any circumstance
Fleeing is always a failure and shows lack of faith
We should give up when trials come
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance includes times of rest and renewal before continuing the mission God has given us
questions.explanation: Elijah fled for safety (1 Kings 19:3), rested under the juniper tree (verse 4-8), then renewed and obeyed God’s call showing perseverance balanced with rest.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 19 teach us about God’s sovereignty over leaders and circumstances?
options: God directs the rise and fall of kings and appoints leaders according to His plan
Leaders come to power by chance without God’s involvement
God ignores political affairs
We should rely only on human strategy without trusting God
questions.correctAnswer: God directs the rise and fall of kings and appoints leaders according to His plan
questions.explanation: God commands Elijah to anoint Hazael, Jehu, and Elisha as leaders (1 Kings 19:15-17), illustrating God’s control over political and spiritual authority.

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 19.

questions.question: What was Jezebel's threat to Elijah after Ahab reported his actions?
options: She would kill him by the next day
She would imprison him
She would exile him to Babylon
She would challenge him to a duel
questions.correctAnswer: She would kill him by the next day
questions.explanation: Jezebel sent a messenger warning Elijah that she would make his life like that of the prophets he had slain by the next day (1 Kings 19:2).

questions.question: Where did Elijah flee after Jezebel's threat?
options: Beersheba
Jerusalem
Samaria
Mount Carmel
questions.correctAnswer: Beersheba
questions.explanation: Elijah fled to Beersheba, which belongs to Judah, and left his servant there (1 Kings 19:3).

questions.question: Under what type of tree did Elijah rest and pray for death?
options: Juniper tree
Olive tree
Cedar tree
Palm tree
questions.correctAnswer: Juniper tree
questions.explanation: Elijah went a day's journey into the wilderness and sat under a juniper tree, requesting that God take his life (1 Kings 19:4).

questions.question: What did the angel provide Elijah to eat and drink during his journey?
options: A cake baked on coals and a cruse of water
Manna and water from a spring
Bread and wine
Figs and milk
questions.correctAnswer: A cake baked on coals and a cruse of water
questions.explanation: An angel touched Elijah and provided him with a cake baked on coals and a cruse of water, which he ate and drank (1 Kings 19:6).

questions.question: How long did Elijah travel strengthened by the food the angel provided?
options: Forty days and forty nights
Seven days and seven nights
Three days and three nights
Twenty days and twenty nights
questions.correctAnswer: Forty days and forty nights
questions.explanation: Elijah ate and drank, then traveled in the strength of that food for forty days and forty nights to Mount Horeb (1 Kings 19:8).

questions.question: What question did God ask Elijah twice while he was at the cave on Mount Horeb?
options: What doest thou here, Elijah?
Why are you afraid?
Do you trust in me?
Will you follow my commands?
questions.correctAnswer: What doest thou here, Elijah?
questions.explanation: God asked Elijah twice, "What doest thou here, Elijah?" emphasizing Elijah's isolation and mission (1 Kings 19:9 and 1 Kings 19:13).

questions.question: Which of the following natural phenomena did NOT contain the LORD's presence when He passed by Mount Horeb?
options: The earthquake
The wind
The fire
The thunder
questions.correctAnswer: The thunder
questions.explanation: The text mentions wind, earthquake, and fire, but not thunder; the LORD was not in the wind, earthquake, or fire but in the still small voice (1 Kings 19:11-12).

questions.question: What literary device is demonstrated by the sequence of wind, earthquake, fire, and then a still small voice in 1 Kings 19:11-12?
options: Chiasm
Parallelism
Gradatio (climax)
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Gradatio (climax)
questions.explanation: The progression from powerful natural events to a still small voice exemplifies gradatio, a climax where intensity decreases to emphasize the subtlety of God's presence (1 Kings 19:11-12).

questions.question: What was Elijah's complaint to God about Israel's spiritual condition?
options: They have forsaken Thy covenant, thrown down Thine altars, and slain Thy prophets
They have worshiped foreign gods openly
They have neglected the Sabbath and the festivals
They have built idols in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They have forsaken Thy covenant, thrown down Thine altars, and slain Thy prophets
questions.explanation: Elijah expressed jealousy for God because Israel had forsaken His covenant, destroyed altars, and killed prophets, leaving Elijah feeling alone (1 Kings 19:10, 14).

questions.question: Who were the three individuals Elijah was commanded to anoint according to God's instructions?
options: Hazael as king of Syria, Jehu as king of Israel, and Elisha as prophet
David as king of Israel, Nathan as prophet, and Solomon as priest
Jeroboam as king, Elijah as prophet, and Elisha as priest
Ahab as king, Jezebel as queen, and Elijah as prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Hazael as king of Syria, Jehu as king of Israel, and Elisha as prophet
questions.explanation: God instructed Elijah to anoint Hazael king over Syria, Jehu king over Israel, and Elisha as prophet in his place (1 Kings 19:15-16).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'seven thousand' mentioned in 1 Kings 19:18?
options: They represent those who have not bowed to Baal or kissed him, symbolizing faithful remnant
They are the number of prophets Elijah had killed
They are the people who fled to Egypt
They are the soldiers of King Ahab
questions.correctAnswer: They represent those who have not bowed to Baal or kissed him, symbolizing faithful remnant
questions.explanation: The seven thousand symbolize the faithful remnant in Israel who remain true to God, contrasting with the widespread idolatry (1 Kings 19:18).

questions.question: What did Elijah do to Elisha when he found him plowing with twelve yoke of oxen?
options: Cast his mantle upon him
Gave him a prophecy
Called him to prayer
Anointed him king
questions.correctAnswer: Cast his mantle upon him
questions.explanation: Elijah symbolically passed his prophetic authority by casting his mantle upon Elisha (1 Kings 19:19).

questions.question: What was Elisha's response after Elijah cast his mantle on him?
options: He left the oxen and ran after Elijah, asking to say goodbye to his parents
He immediately left without looking back
He refused and continued plowing
He returned home to prepare
questions.correctAnswer: He left the oxen and ran after Elijah, asking to say goodbye to his parents
questions.explanation: Elisha left the oxen and asked to kiss his father and mother before following Elijah (1 Kings 19:20).

questions.question: What act did Elisha perform before fully following Elijah as his servant?
options: He slaughtered a yoke of oxen and boiled their flesh for the people
He built an altar to the LORD
He fasted for seven days
He offered sacrifices at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He slaughtered a yoke of oxen and boiled their flesh for the people
questions.explanation: Elisha killed oxen, boiled their meat, and gave it to the people to eat before following Elijah (1 Kings 19:21).

questions.question: True or False: Elijah was alone as the only prophet left in Israel according to his own words.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Elijah claimed he was the only one left and that others sought to take his life (1 Kings 19:10,14).

questions.question: True or False: The LORD was revealed in the powerful wind, earthquake, and fire at Mount Horeb.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The LORD was not in the wind, earthquake, or fire but appeared in a still small voice (1 Kings 19:11-12).

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 19 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was Elijah's initial reaction upon learning of Jezebel's threat to his life?
options: He fled to Beersheba and left his servant there
He immediately confronted Jezebel
He prayed for strength to fight
He hid in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He fled to Beersheba and left his servant there
questions.explanation: Elijah fled to Beersheba, which belongs to Judah, and left his servant there as a response to Jezebel's threat, showing his fear and desire to escape (1 Kings 19:3). This illustrates human frailty under threat, consistent with Moses' flight in Exodus 2:15 and David's fleeing in 1 Samuel 19:10. Elijah's flight underscores the need for God's sustaining grace as later seen in Psalm 34:18 and Matthew 11:28.

questions.question: How did God provide for Elijah's physical needs during his journey in the wilderness?
options: An angel gave him food and water twice
He found manna on the ground
Ravens brought him meat and bread
He drank from a spring and ate wild berries
questions.correctAnswer: An angel gave him food and water twice
questions.explanation: God sent an angel to touch Elijah and provide food and water twice, sustaining him for a 40-day journey (1 Kings 19:5-7). This echoes God's provision of manna for Israel in Exodus 16:4 and Elijah's earlier provision by ravens in 1 Kings 17:6. It illustrates God's care for the physical needs of His servants, reflected also in Psalm 104:14-15 and Jesus' teaching in Matthew 6:31-33.

questions.question: What was Elijah's emotional state under the juniper tree, and what does it reveal about human nature?
options: He was despondent and wished to die, revealing human despair under pressure
He was joyful and praising God
He was angry and planning revenge
He was indifferent and apathetic
questions.correctAnswer: He was despondent and wished to die, revealing human despair under pressure
questions.explanation: Elijah requested for his life to be taken, saying 'It is enough,' showing deep despair and exhaustion (1 Kings 19:4). This reflects human vulnerability to discouragement, consistent with Jonah's similar despair in Jonah 4:3 and David's laments in Psalm 42:5. It highlights the need for God's comfort as promised in 2 Corinthians 1:3-4 and Jesus' invitation in Matthew 11:28.

questions.question: Which manifestation of God did Elijah ultimately hear at Mount Horeb?
options: A still small voice
A great and strong wind
An earthquake
A fire
questions.correctAnswer: A still small voice
questions.explanation: Elijah experienced God not in the wind, earthquake, or fire, but in a still small voice (1 Kings 19:11-12). This reveals God's transcendence and immanence, contrasting dramatic natural phenomena with intimate personal revelation. It parallels God's self-revelation to Moses in Exodus 3:2-4 and Jesus' teaching about the Spirit in John 14:26, emphasizing God's quiet, sovereign presence.

questions.question: What commission did God give Elijah after his encounter at Mount Horeb?
options: To anoint Hazael, Jehu, and Elisha for their respective roles
To return to Jezebel and confront her
To build a temple on Mount Horeb
To lead an army against Syria
questions.correctAnswer: To anoint Hazael, Jehu, and Elisha for their respective roles
questions.explanation: God instructed Elijah to anoint Hazael as king of Syria, Jehu as king of Israel, and Elisha as prophet in his place (1 Kings 19:15-16). This prophetic commissioning shows God's sovereign governance over nations and His plan for prophetic succession, consistent with the call of Samuel (1 Samuel 3:10), the anointing of David (1 Samuel 16:13), and Jesus' commissioning of the disciples (Matthew 28:18-20).

questions.question: How did Elijah explain his sense of isolation in his prophetic mission?
options: He said he was the only one left who was faithful
He claimed he was the most powerful prophet
He said the people were all faithful
He said he had many supporters among the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: He said he was the only one left who was faithful
questions.explanation: Elijah claimed that he alone was left faithful to the LORD because Israel had forsaken the covenant and killed the prophets (1 Kings 19:10,14). This feeling of isolation reflects the experience of faithful servants in Scripture, like Jeremiah (Jeremiah 15:17) and Paul (Romans 3:9-18). It underscores the reality of spiritual opposition and the need for God's reassurance (Isaiah 41:10, Hebrews 13:5).

questions.question: What does the presence of seven thousand in Israel who have not bowed to Baal signify about God's covenant faithfulness?
options: God preserves a faithful remnant despite widespread apostasy
No one remained faithful except Elijah
All Israelites had abandoned the covenant
The nation was entirely devoted to Baal worship
questions.correctAnswer: God preserves a faithful remnant despite widespread apostasy
questions.explanation: God revealed that seven thousand remained in Israel who had not bowed to Baal or kissed him, illustrating His preservation of a faithful remnant (1 Kings 19:18). This theme of a remnant is central throughout Scripture, seen in Isaiah's promise of a remnant (Isaiah 10:20-22), Paul's teaching on remnant in Romans 11:5, and the preservation of the church in Revelation 12:17. It emphasizes God's covenant faithfulness and mercy.

questions.question: What symbolic act did Elijah perform to call Elisha to prophetic ministry?
options: He cast his mantle upon him
He gave him a scroll of the law
He anointed him with oil
He shared a meal with him
questions.correctAnswer: He cast his mantle upon him
questions.explanation: Elijah cast his mantle upon Elisha as a symbolic act of calling and transferring prophetic authority (1 Kings 19:19). This act signifies the passing of God's calling and is echoed in the New Testament where the laying on of hands signifies commissioning (2 Timothy 1:6). It also parallels the anointing of prophets and kings (1 Samuel 16:13) and the commissioning of disciples (Matthew 10:1).

questions.question: What was Elisha's initial response when Elijah called him?
options: He asked to bid farewell to his parents before following
He immediately left his work and followed
He refused the call
He requested to take over immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He asked to bid farewell to his parents before following
questions.explanation: Elisha requested to kiss his father and mother before following Elijah, demonstrating respect for family and proper closure before ministry (1 Kings 19:20). Elijah's response, 'Go back again,' indicates a test of commitment. This interaction reflects biblical balance between family responsibilities and divine call, as seen in Jesus' teaching in Luke 14:26-27 and Paul's instructions in 1 Timothy 5:8.

questions.question: What did Elisha do after initially returning home upon Elijah's call?
options: He slaughtered his oxen and used the equipment to prepare a meal for the people
He continued plowing the fields
He built an altar to the LORD
He sent a message to Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: He slaughtered his oxen and used the equipment to prepare a meal for the people
questions.explanation: Elisha slaughtered his oxen, boiled their flesh with the instruments, and gave it to the people to eat before fully committing to follow Elijah (1 Kings 19:21). This act symbolizes renouncing his old life and dedicating himself to God's work, similar to Jesus' call to discipleship in Luke 9:62 and Paul's call to leave old customs in Romans 6:6.

questions.question: What theological truth is revealed by Elijah’s experience of God not being in dramatic natural events, but in a still small voice?
options: God’s presence is often revealed in quietness rather than spectacle
God is only present in powerful natural phenomena
God cannot be known through personal experience
God only reveals Himself through fire and earthquakes
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence is often revealed in quietness rather than spectacle
questions.explanation: Elijah's encounter shows that God's presence and guidance can come through gentle, quiet means rather than dramatic events (1 Kings 19:11-12). This aligns with Jesus’ teaching about the Spirit's subtle work (John 3:8), God speaking to Samuel softly (1 Samuel 3:10), and the peace God provides in Philippians 4:7. It challenges views that God must always act visibly or powerfully.

questions.question: In what way does Elijah’s journey to Mount Horeb illustrate the doctrine of divine providence?
options: God sustains and guides His servants even in times of weakness and fear
God abandons His servants when they are afraid
Elijah’s success depended solely on his own strength
God only acts through miraculous signs
questions.correctAnswer: God sustains and guides His servants even in times of weakness and fear
questions.explanation: Elijah’s journey, provision by an angel, and encounter with God demonstrate God’s providential care even when Elijah is fearful and discouraged (1 Kings 19:4-8). This is consistent with God's providence over Israel (Psalm 23:1-4), Jesus' teaching on God caring for sparrows (Matthew 10:29-31), and Paul’s trust in God’s guidance (Romans 8:28). It affirms that God works through human weakness.

questions.question: What does the commission to anoint kings and a prophet reveal about God's sovereignty?
options: God exercises sovereign control over nations and appoints leaders
God leaves human governments entirely to chance
Prophets have no role in political affairs
Kings and prophets act independently of God
questions.correctAnswer: God exercises sovereign control over nations and appoints leaders
questions.explanation: God’s command to Elijah to anoint Hazael, Jehu, and Elisha shows that God ordains rulers and prophets to fulfill His purposes (1 Kings 19:15-16). This theme resonates with God’s sovereignty in appointing Cyrus (Isaiah 45:1), David (Acts 13:22), and the ultimate reign of Christ (Revelation 19:16). It assures believers of God's control over history (Daniel 2:21).

questions.question: How does Elijah’s declaration about the children of Israel forsaking God reflect the reality of sin and covenant violation?
options: It shows Israel’s breach of the covenant through idolatry and violence against prophets
It indicates Israel remained fully faithful
It denies any sin in Israel
It praises Israel’s righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: It shows Israel’s breach of the covenant through idolatry and violence against prophets
questions.explanation: Elijah states that Israel forsook God's covenant, threw down altars, and killed prophets (1 Kings 19:10,14), highlighting covenant unfaithfulness and sin. This reflects the covenant curses in Deuteronomy 28 and the prophetic call to repentance in Jeremiah 2:13. The New Testament parallels include warnings against apostasy (Hebrews 3:12) and the call to faithfulness (Revelation 2:5).

questions.question: What does Elijah’s wrapping of his face in his mantle signify in his encounter with God?
options: Reverence and preparation to receive God's revelation
Fear of physical harm
Disobedience to God
Indifference to God's presence
questions.correctAnswer: Reverence and preparation to receive God's revelation
questions.explanation: Elijah wrapped his face in his mantle before standing at the cave entrance to hear God's voice (1 Kings 19:13), symbolizing reverence and awe. This is comparable to Moses veiling his face after seeing God’s glory (Exodus 34:33-35) and the biblical motif of hiding one’s face in God's presence (Isaiah 6:5). It expresses humility and readiness for divine encounter.
